content: new mom of Airman 1st class Michael stationed at Shaw AFB Been told a couple of times from vets that I am entitled to benifits (medical)and discounts to on baseor nearby lodging but will need an identification number to access things like that. Anyone out there with info? Surfed the web, but dont find much about "parents of"

title: New Mom of....

content: As the parent of a member of the military I don't believe you are entitled to any benefits. The benefits you are talking about are for the service member, the spouse of the service member, and the children of the service member. Just curious though, why would you think you would be entitled to military benefits because your son joined the Air Force? "The price of freedom is eternal vigilance." Thomas Jefferson
reply: As the parent of a member of the military I don't believe you are entitled to any benefits. The benefits you are talking about are for the service member, the spouse of the service member, and the children of the service member. Just curious though, why would you think you would be entitled to military benefits because your son joined the Air Force? "The price of freedom is eternal vigilance." Thomas Jefferson
title: New Mom of....

content: quote: new mom of Airman 1st class Michael stationed at Shaw AFB Been told a couple of times from vets that I am entitled to benifits (medical)and discounts to on baseor nearby lodging but will need an identification number to access things like that. Anyone out there with info? Surfed the web, but dont find much about "parents of" First, welcome to military.com. Here is a forum that I suggest you visit Parent of Servicemembers Now, the short answer is “NO!” unless it can be established that you are dependent upon the member for more than 50 of your support. Much like if he can claim you on his tax return you don’t qualify. Last week I attended AF BMT graduation at Lackland. The air force gave a briefing to new airman and their families that specifically covered that question. I was a little confused by your opening statement new mom of Airman 1st class Michael is that to mean that he is new or that your are his new mom? I assume it is that he is new. We all wish you and Michael both the very best of every thing, Please keep us posted. God and the soldier, All men adore, In time of trouble, And no more; For when war is over, And all things righted, God is neglected - The old soldier slighted. Founding Member Original DVG & Proud Member, Rupterd Duck/Derelict Veterans

reply: First, welcome to military.com. Here is a forum that I suggest you visit Parent of Servicemembers Now, the short answer is “NO!” unless it can be established that you are dependent upon the member for more than 50 of your support. Much like if he can claim you on his tax return you don’t qualify. Last week I attended AF BMT graduation at Lackland. The air force gave a briefing to new airman and their families that specifically covered that question. I was a little confused by your opening statement new mom of Airman 1st class Michael is that to mean that he is new or that your are his new mom? I assume it is that he is new. We all wish you and Michael both the very best of every thing, Please keep us posted. God and the soldier, All men adore, In time of trouble, And no more; For when war is over, And all things righted, God is neglected - The old soldier slighted. content: YES, it's my son that is new. At his graduation day, it stormed out at lackland and all festivities were cancelled. They were very disapointed not to show us their stuff! As per benefits, Ive a friend who tells me I need and identification card and blah, blah blah. Also I just recieved in the mail a package from Tricare.

title: New Mom of....

content: I know that the airmen would have loved to demonstrate the good stuff in front of their loved loves. If he has claimed you as a dependent and you has met the qualification, then you should receive the benefits. I claimed my mother for the first five years of my military life. She had no income and no resources other than what the kids provided. I had to prove it to the military ever year. I claimed her on my tax returns and and she filed even though she didn't have to and did not claim herself. I had been her sole support for two years prior to enlisting. Your son would also have had to enroll you in Defense Enrollment Eligibility Reporting System. Here's the link: DEERS Again, I wish you, your son and other loved ones the very best of everything. Bruce Please keep us posted! God and the soldier, All men adore, In time of trouble, And no more; For when war is over, And all things righted, God is neglected - The old soldier slighted. Founding Member Original DVG & Proud Member, Rupterd Duck/Derelict Veterans
